comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Ordinance Survey The photo was taken from the grounds of the Railway Hotel, subsequently The Great Sothern Hotel and now the malton Hotel.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Comment? The only thing that strikes me is the bench, facing the shrubs. Shouldn't it face the other way, so you don't get to look at the bushes? Look out over the courtyard instead...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Wikipedia says the Great Southern Railway operated from 1925 to'45. It is perhaps the Great Southern and Western Railway, operating from 1844 to 1924. That was a broad-gauge railroad (1.6m 5'3" between the rails). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Southern_and_Western_Railway

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Seems to now be an IÉ terminal known asCill Airne (or Killarney in English). www.sinfin.net/railways/stations/sta-gael-ireland.html

comment.author: 40708286@N07
comment._content: That bench will be used to look at a garden full of flowers looking at those seedlings.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] All non-narrow gauge irish railways were 5'3". It's not really broad gauge as such; just a bit less meagre than our british and continental cousins use.

comment._content: Unfortunately there is no streetview available of this but here's a recent photo of the station www.flickr.com/photos/be216cd1/6413119089/

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02]  I like that... Things are bigger in Ireland!
